The '''National Theatre of the Deaf''' ('''NTD''') was founded in 1967 and is the oldest [[theatre company]] in the [[United States]] with a continuous history of domestic and international touring and producing original works.<ref name="NTD History">{{cite web|url=http://www.ntd.org/ntd_history.html|title=National Theatre of the Deaf - HISTORY|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=NTD|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=April 19, 2018}}</ref> NTD productions combine [[American Sign Language]] with [[spoken language]] to fulfill the theatre's [[mission statement]] of linking [[Hearing loss|deaf]] and [[hearing]] communities and educating the public about [[Deaf culture|Deaf art]]. The NTD is affiliated with a [[Acting School|drama school]], also founded in 1967, and with the Little Theatre of the Deaf (LTD), established in 1968 to produce shows for a younger audience.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntd.org/ltd_about.html|title=ABOUT the Little Theatre of the Deaf|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=NTD|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=April 19, 2018}}</ref>
The first official performance of the NTD was at [[Wesleyan University]] in 1967.<ref name="NTD American Theatre Company">{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/National-Theatre-of-the-Deaf|title=National Theatre of the Deaf American Theatre Company|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Britannica|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=April 3, 2018}}</ref> NTD members participated in the first National and Worldwide Deaf Theatre Conference in 1994. Many deaf actors have earned acclaim through their work with the NTD in performances, conferences, and community outreach. The NTD has been fundamental in the creation of an international Deaf theatre community, and has received several awards, including the [[Tony Award]] for Theatrical Excellence. The company has visited each of the [[Fifty States|50 states]] during over 150 national tours, as well as over 30 countries.
== Founding == In 1946, [[Robert Panara]], a [[Gallaudet University]] graduate and newly hired teacher at the [[New York School for the Deaf]], produced a play with [[Bernard Bragg]], a 17-year-old student in Panara's English class.<ref name="Powers">{{cite book|title=Signs of Silence: Bernard Bragg and the National Theatre of the Deaf|last=Powers|first=Helen|date=1972|publisher=Dodd, Mead|year=|isbn=|location=New York|page=51|pages=}}</ref> Later in the 1940s, when Bragg was a student at Gallaudet, Panara left New York School for the Deaf to teach at Gallaudet. While both at Gallaudet, Panara and Bragg conceived of the idea of a theater for the deaf.<ref>Powers, Helen (1972). ''Signs of Silence: Bernard Bragg and the National Theatre of the Deaf''. New York: Dodd, Mead. p. 72.</ref>
In 1963, Dr. Edna Levine, a professor of [[Deaf studies]] at [[New York University]], saw Bragg perform a [[one-man show]] in [[New York City]]. She asked him for a meeting and shared her own vision for a national theater for the deaf.<ref>Powers, Helen (1972). ''Signs of Silence: Bernard Bragg and the National Theatre of the Deaf''. New York: Dodd, Mead. p. 119.</ref> In 1965, they obtained a federal grant from the [[U.S. Department of Health, Education, and Welfare]] to establish the NTD. Additional grant money was given by the [[Office of Education]].<ref name="NTD American Theatre Company" /> [[Mary E. Switzer]] of the Department of Health, Education, and Welfare and Boyce R. Williams and Malcolm Norwood of the [[Rehabilitation Services Administration]] were important advocates of funding the NTD.<ref name="Baldwin" />
Levine and Bragg worked with [[set designer]] David Hays to establish a mission statement, locate funding, select a location, and assemble a company. The founders also included [[Ann Bancroft]], who played [[Annie Sullivan]] in the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production of ''[[The Miracle Worker (play)|The Miracle Worker]]'', and [[Arthur Penn]] and Gene Lasko, directors of ''The Miracle Worker''.<ref name="Baldwin">{{cite book|title=Pictures in the Air: The Story of the National Theatre of the Deaf|last=Baldwin|first=Stephen C.|date=1993|publisher=[[Gallaudet University Press]]|year=|isbn=|location=Washington, DC|page=|pages=}}</ref>
==Mission and location==
The founders' mission was to feature sign language in the theater for both deaf and hearing audiences. The founders believed that audience members need to “hear every word and see every word” in all NTD productions.<ref name="NTD Mission">{{cite web|url=http://www.ntd.org/ntd_mission.html|title=National Theatre of the Deaf MISSION|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=NTD|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=April 19, 2018}}</ref> To fulfill this mission, productions included both deaf and hearing actors. The language used by the deaf performers included sign language, [[Mime artist|mime]], and [[gesture]], and the hearing actors provided spoken language. Bragg had studied under the French mime [[Marcel Marceau]], and his acting style influenced the early NTD productions.<ref>Powers, Helen (1972). ''Signs of Silence: Bernard Bragg and the National Theatre of the Deaf''. New York: Dodd, Mead. p. 115.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bernardbragg.com/biography/|title=Act One: It All Began on Metropolitan Street|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=BernardBragg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=April 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bernardbragg.com/|title=Honored With NTD Award|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=BernardBragg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=April 19, 2018}}</ref>
Originally, the NTD was located on the campus of the [[Eugene O'Neill Theatre Center]] in [[Waterford, Connecticut]]. In 1983, the NTD moved to [[Chester, Connecticut]].<ref name="Baldwin" />{{rp|63-64}} In 2000, the NTD moved to [[Hartford, CT|Hartford, Connecticut]], and in 2004 moved onto the campus of the [[American School for the Deaf]] in [[West Hartford, CT|West Hartford]]. Since 2012, the NTD has again been based at the O'Neill Theatre Center while maintaining a satellite office on the campus of the American School for the Deaf.<ref name="NTD American Theatre Company" />
==Actors, instructors, and curriculum== The founding company included:
* Violet Armstrong * Bernard Bragg * Charles Corey * Gilbert Eastman * [[Lou Fant]] * Ed Fearon * Joyce Flynn Lasko * [[Phyllis Frelich]] * [[Dorothy Miles]] * Mary Beth Miller * [[Audree Norton]] * Howard Palmer * Will Rhys * June Russi * Tim Scanlon * Morton Steinberg * Andrew Vasnick * Joe Velez * Ralph White<ref name="Baldwin" />{{rp|125-129}}
Early instructors in the school included:
* Bernard Bragg * Eric Malzkuhn * Bob Panara * Sahome Tachibana * Gina Blau * William Rhys * George C. White III<ref name="Baldwin" />
The school's curriculum included:
* Acting * Mime * Bodily movement * [[Stagecraft]] * Lighting * Costuming * History of theater * Creative dance * [[Japanese dance]] * Hindu movement * Tumbling * [[Fencing]]<ref name="Baldwin" />
===Notable actors===
[[Phyllis Frelich]] received the [[Tony Award for Best Actress in a Play]] in 1980 for ''[[Children of a Lesser God (play)|Children of a Lesser God]]'', produced by the [[Mark Taper Forum]] in [[Los Angeles]].
[[Linda Bove]] appeared regularly on the television series ''[[Sesame Street]]''.
Other actors who have worked with NTD include [[Colleen Dewhurst]], [[Sir Michael Redgrave]], [[Chita Rivera]], [[Jason Robards]], and [[Meryl Streep]].<ref>Smith, Helen C. "National theater troupe breathes life into words," ''[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]'', January 29, 1988.</ref> While some NTD actors have achieved recognition in hearing theatre, a greater number of Deaf actors, including [[Chuck Baird]], Eric Malzkuhn, [[Ed Waterstreet]], Gilberst Eastman, Mary Beth Miller, and Manny Hernandez, have achieved recognition primarily within deaf theatre.
Though not an NTD actor, [[Lauren Ridloff]], the actress cast as Sarah in the 2018 revival of ''[[Children of a Lesser God (play)|Children of a Lesser God]]'', was nominated in May 2018 for a Tony Award for Best Actress in a Play.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/01/theater/tony-awards-nominees-list.htm|title=Tony Awards 2018 Full List of Nominations|last=|first=|date=|website=New York Times|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=May 6, 2018}}</ref>
==Productions, touring, and reception==
Rehearsals and performances occupied most of each day for both company actors and students. The company toured by [[bus]] both domestically and internationally, received only [[Part-time contract|part-time]] pay, and paid [[Out-of-pocket expense|out-of-pocket]] for their travel.<ref name="Baldwin" />{{rp|125-129}} Both the company and the students lived [[dormitory]]-style at the O'Neill Theatre Center while rehearsing, and slept either on the bus or in inexpensive hotels while touring domestically. While touring internationally, the actors stayed in [[Hostel|hostels]].<ref name="Baldwin" /><ref name="Bragg">{{cite book|title=Lessons in Laughter: The Autobiography of a Deaf Actor|last=Bragg|first=Bernard|date=1989|publisher=Gallaudet University Press|year=|isbn=|location=Washington, DC|pages=}}</ref>
The company performed both traditional plays and plays written by Deaf playwrights.<ref name="Baldwin" />{{rp|121-124}} Hearing audiences have typically had positive responses to NTD productions, while Deaf and [[Hard-of-hearing|Hard of Hearing]] audiences have often had mixed reviews. Deaf and Hard of Hearing audience members sometimes expected productions to be more focused around the Deaf experience, and to be less highly dramatized. Some Deaf audience members have seen NTD productions as catering to Hearing audiences, which has generated a negative response. However, many Deaf audience members have responded positively and appreciated NTD productions.<ref name="Baldwin" />{{rp|115-116}}
The NTD has been discussed in newspapers such as ''[[Silent News]]'', journals such as the ''Puppetry Journal'', and television shows such as ''Deaf Mosaic'', which aired during the 1980s and 1990s. Many scholars have written about the NTD in books and [[dissertations]].<ref name="Baldwin" />{{rp|24-25; 41-42; 55-56; 70-71; 83-84; 95-96; 109-110; 117-118}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ntd.org/ NTD.org]
{{DEFAULTSORT:National Theatre Of The Deaf}} [[Category:Theatre companies in Connecticut]] [[Category:Deaf culture in the United States]] [[Category:Deafness arts organizations]]

page.title: NinKi: Urgency of Proximate Drawing Photograph

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox project | name = NinKi: Urgency of Proximate Drawing Photograph (NinKi:UoPDP) | logo = | image = Uopdp1.JPG | caption = Proximate Drawing Photograph | mission_statement = | commercial = | type = | products = Proximate Drawing Photos | location = [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] | owner = [[Firoz Mahmud]] | founder = [[Firoz Mahmud]] | key_people = | established = 2008 | disestablished = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | funding = 2008 | current_status = | website = http://urgency-of-proximate-drawing-ninki.blogspot.com/ }}
'''The NinKi: Urgency of Proximate Drawing Photograph''' (NinKi:UoPDP)[http://urgency-of-proximate-drawing-ninki.blogspot.com/] was initiated by [[Bangladesh]]i visual artist [[Firoz Mahmud]] ( ফিরোজ মাহমুদ, フィロズ・マハムド ). This is a drawing photograph project to rhetorically rescue popular icons with geometric structure drawings or make photo image of the people tactically static. His pigeonhole or kind of compartmental examples of doodling were engaged on found images in various printed media and also were found in his sketchbook, books, notebooks and often in his borrowed books. The word '[https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E3%81%AB%E3%82%93%E3%81%8D#Japanese Ninki'] (人気) is a [[Japanese language|Japanese]] word which means be Popular or popularity. The Ninki: UoPDP art Project of drawing on photographs consist of numerous archetypal images of popular celebrities in vague appearance. Their career, character, fame, obscurity, activities and character are insurgent and idiosyncratic. Artist Firoz has started on any image and then specifically on Bengal tiger and more significantly on Japanese [[Sumo]] Wrestler as artist based in [[Japan]] and fascinated by sports, media and interested on humorous aspect of entertainment [[industries]].
==About== The `Urgency of Proximate Drawing Photograph` (NinKi:UoPDP)[http://urgency-of-proximate-drawing-ninki.blogspot.com/] is [[Firoz Mahmud]]`s one of art projects, started as anonymously. Gradually with the requests of curators and many of his friends, he started to exhibit in public spaces and major art venues. It was initially created for changing the meaning of visual images from the original photo images which Firoz took, collected or found to experiment that how general people react seeing each one's popular icons.
==History== From the inception when [[Firoz Mahmud]] exposed these drawing photographs, he focused anonymously without using his name at billboards, undergrounds, signage board or in other exhibition venues in Japan. He created this on-going art project in [[Tokyo]] since 2008 as his leisure time drawing doodle on newspapers, magazines, and found images. NinKi: Urgency of Proximate Drawing was first exhibited at the 9th Sharjah Art Biennial in 2009 in Sharjah, UAE. Gradually he exhibited in Museums, galleries and art spaces.Gradually with the requests of curators and many of his friends, he started to exhibit in public spaces and major art venues. One of his first projects of 'Urgency of Proximate Drawing' was exhibited as [http://www.hiroshima-moca.jp/docs/press/dokodemo2011_1.pdf 'Rescued Stardom'] project at the Hiroshima City Museum of Contemporary Art in Hiroshima Japan where he received a prize.
==Topic of the project and style== Firoz focuses on celebrities in excited, playful, sporty and happy moments. He draws remarkable lines where they are about to fall or feel hard to gesture in the photographs. Their idolized appearances are highlighted by protective line drawings that display an awareness of the per-formative ethos of iconic expression. The lines underneath the falling position imply that the stardom can`t fall down from the gestures and positions that they are held in.
==Reviews, Comments and Quotes== The project The NinKi: Urgency of Proximate Drawing Photograph [http://urgency-of-proximate-drawing-ninki.blogspot.com/] has been featured in many newspapers and magazines. Many critics, artists and art specialists commented on Firoz's NinKi art project, for example: `Through a very unique point of view, Firoz focuses on a moment of people’s lives. Although his method is very simple, it reconstructs the space in a very strong way. His works give viewers a lot of excitement. ``- Ozawa Tsuyoshi, Artist based in [[Japan]][http://urgency-of-proximate-drawing-ninki.blogspot.com/] [[New York City]] & [[Dhaka]] based writer & artist [[Naeem Mohaiemen]] wrote on his reviews in [http://www.departmag.com/index.php/en/detail/177/Firoz-wants-to-fight-Tyson Depart art Magazine] that, - "Firoz's announced plan is to rescue icons from detritus, but something sinister is at play in these brutalist lines. The crazy cat's cradle across a former pugilist's face, a flesh-eating phantasm in its pre-animation wireframe, is channeling Tyson's unmoored, chaotic, fractured id.[http://www.departmag.com/index.php/en/detail/177/Firoz-wants-to-fight-Tyson]
" Firoz has artfully and humorously explored social and emotive issues through his "NINKi :UoPDP" Urgency of Proximate Drawings. I am surprised how he magically rescued the perturbed stars during their danger situation in the photographs. The drawing structures are drawn with geometric patterns that appear like protective hex symbols. All celebrities can eventually remain invincible in their popularity, protected by an uncanny force." - Lucy Birmingham is an [[United States|American]] critic and [[journalist]] based in [[Tokyo]], but her articles appeared in [[Japan Times]], Time.com, Wall Street Journal, ARTFORUM Magazine, Artinfo.com, Artforum.com, [[ARTnews]].
==Exhibition== * Exhibit 320, Part of `NinKi, Legacies Run over the [[Yamuna]][https://www.artsy.net/show/exhibit-320-ninki-leagacies-run-over-the-yamuna]` [[New Delhi]], [[India]], 2015 [http://ocula.com/art-galleries/exhibit320/exhibitions/ninki-legacies-run-over-the-yamuna][[File:Uopdp4.JPG|thumb]] * Dhaka Art center, [[Dhaka]], 2013, `Loss of the Toss is Blessing of Their Disguise` September, 2013.[https://web.archive.org/web/20150711213855/http://news.priyo.com/2013/09/12/solo-exhibition-loss-toss-blessing-their-disguise-85461.html] * "[http://www.aaa.org.hk/WorldEvents/Details/19263 STEP ACROSS THIS LINE]", Contemporary Art from [[Bangladesh]], [[India]] and [[Pakistan]] at [[Asia House]], [[London]] 10–22 October 2011 [https://web.archive.org/web/20150615111555/http://grosvenorgallery.com/exhibitions/past-exhibitions/2011-2/step-across-this-line/] * [[New York City]] Subways and Billboards project, [[New York City]], May~ September, 2011 [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/step-across-this-line--picture-preview-2369871.html?action=gallery&ino=30] * International studio and Curatorial Program [ISCP], May 2011 * [[New York City]], Underground and public spaces, 2011, `I buy, you frame-10% taxand 100% discount-[[Firoz Mahmud]]`s NinKI: UoPD (Urgency of Proximate Drawing is on SALE)`[[File:Uopdp2.jpg|thumb]] * [[Hiroshima]], Hiroshima Museum of Contemporary Art, 2009, `Rescued Stardom` (Art Project Ideas with prize)[http://www.hiroshima-moca.jp/dokodemo/archive/2009.html][[File:Uopdp3.JPG|thumb]] * [[Bandung]], [[Indonesia]], 2010, Asbestos Art Space & City public space,`Whatever They are Scolded Your Star is Safe`[http://www.art-it.asia/u/otafinearts/rwoDSzlGQUs6fB2VcvP9?lang=en] * [[Tokyo]], Undergrounds NinKi:UoPD project,`Loss of the Toss is Blessing of Their Disguise`, 2010 * [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]], B.A.D. Museum of Contemporary Art Yuga Gallery, [[Tokyo University of the Arts]], 2010, `Yatta ! Anzen ! ` * [[UAE]], [[Sharjah Biennale]] 2009, [[Sharjah (emirate)|Sharjah]],`RRR (Ralley Round Rajah) at Halcyon Tarp Project [http://www.sharjahart.org/biennial/sharjah-biennial-9/participating-artists] * [[Niigata, Niigata|Niigata]], Echigo-Tsumari Art Triennale (Conquering Snow Dynamo Art Project/ CAP-Crystal Art Project) [[Japan]] ,2009 * [[Tokyo]], [[The University of the Arts]], 2008 [http://universes-in-universe.org/eng/bien/sharjah_biennial/2009/artists_exhibition]
==Awards== * NinKi: Urgency of Proximate Drawing project was awarded a prize from the Hiroshima City Museum of Contemporary Art, Hiroshima for Art Project Ideas in 2009.[http://www.hiroshima-moca.jp/dokodemo/archive/2009.html] * Osaka Center for Contemporary Art in Osaka awarded him as one of four shortlisted for Jiro Ishihara Memorial Art Prize.[http://www.art-it.asia/u/hmoca/oz091JZuUBmFgh6rHWtx] * Book was published on NinKi: Urgency of Proximate Drawing in 2011.[https://www.createspace.com/3658381]
==References== * https://www.artsy.net/artwork/firoz-mahmud-yatta-anzen-aa9-ninki-uopdp-ninki-urgency-of-proximate-drawing-photograph * http://allevents.in/dhaka/firoz-mahmud-|-solo-%60loss-of-the-toss-is-blessing-of-their-disguise%60-|-3~12-sep2013-|-dhaka-art-cent/1405199553030249# * News Priyo published -Dhaka Art Center Presents Firoz Mahmud’s solo exhibition `Loss of the Toss is Blessing of Their Disguise`, https://web.archive.org/web/20150711213855/http://news.priyo.com/2013/09/12/solo-exhibition-loss-toss-blessing-their-disguise-85461.html * https://web.archive.org/web/20150923214336/http://www.dhakatribune.com/arts-amp-culture/2013/sep/09/firoz-mahmud%E2%80%99s-art-show-presents-controversial-celebs * http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/famous-and-controversial-personalities-under-the-lens/ * http://www.exhibit320.com/artists/download/AR0000153.pdf from 25 March to 24 April in 2015. * http://www.sunday-guardian.com/artbeat/authenticity-in-an-age-of-technology-and-propaganda * http://urgency-of-proximate-drawing-ninki.blogspot.com/
==External links== * http://urgency-of-proximate-drawing-ninki.blogspot.com/ * http://www.departmag.com/index.php/en/detail/177/Firoz-wants-to-fight-Tyson * https://www.academia.edu/1359372/Firoz_wants_to_fight_Tyson

{{Infobox organization |name = Philadelphia/Tri State Artists Equity Association, Inc. |image = |image_border = |size = 250px |alt = |caption = Artists Equity Logo |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = A Professional Association of Fine Artists fostering Excellence and Economic Advancement |formation = 1949, independent 1997 |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = |headquarters = 22 Laurelgate Place
Millersville, PA 17551 |location = |coords = |region_served = [[Delaware Valley]] |membership = |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = Karen Kappe Nugent |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = http://www.artistsequity.org |remarks = }} '''Philadelphia/Tri State Artists Equity Association, Inc.''', commonly known as '''Philadelphia Artists Equity''', became an independent organization in 1997. It was founded as a chapter of a national organization of professional fine artists in 1949. Artists Equity works for the protection of artists’ rights and improved working and economic conditions for fine artists.{{cite web | url = http://www.artistsequity.org/about.html | title = Committed to service: OUR HISTORY | accessdate = 2010-07-02 | date = 2010-07-02 | work = Organization web site | publisher = Philadelphia/Tri State Artists Equity Association, Inc.}} Artists Equity worked behind the scenes for the establishment of a [[Philadelphia]] City ordinance, entitled “Aesthetic Ornamentation of City Structures,” which was sponsored by Councilman Henry Sawyer, III, and adopted on his last day as a member of [[Philadelphia City Council|City Council]] in the final months of 1959. This ordinance established a requirement for [[Percent for Art|one percent for art]] for city building projects.{{cite book | last = Bach | first = Penny Balkin | title = Public Art in Philadelphia | publisher=Temple University Press|location=Philadelphia|year= 1992|isbn=0-87722-822-1|pages= 130–131}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Arts organizations based in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Organizations based in Philadelphia]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1949]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1949]] {{philadelphia-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=May 2009}} A '''production coordinator''' (officially called '''production office coordinator''' and abbreviated '''POC''') is a unionized position in [[stagecraft]] under the [[International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees]] (IATSE) and is governed in Los Angeles by Local 871.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ialocal871.org/|title=Local 871's website|publisher=Local 871|accessdate=23 March 2012}}</ref>
The production coordinator serves under the production manager, producer or UPM to coordinate the various groups and personnel that come together in [[filmmaking]] to a movie and [[video production]] to make a [[television show]]. It is a supervisory position to the [[Production assistant]] staff. The position requires adept organizational skills, resourcefulness and the ability to handle a multitude of tasks simultaneously under often high-pressure situations. The POC serves as the gatekeeper of company policy and is usually responsible for ensuring the rest of the production [[television crew]] follows the requirements of the Production Company or Studio.
The duties of a POC are often undefined and extremely varied ranging from office manager, to human resources, to controller, to accountant. The POC is one of the only positions with the IATSE (USA and Canada) which no longer has a scale or set wage. The IA bylaws simply state the POC’s wage is “subject to negotiation with the Producer”. Fringe benefits include inclusion with the (USA)industry’s Motion Picture Industry Pension & Health Plans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mpiphp.org/faqs/pension_faqs.htm/|title=Motion Picture Pension Plan FAQ|publisher=Motion Picture Industry Pension Plan|accessdate=23 March 2012}}</ref> Currently the production company is required to contribute 60 pensions hours per week, which equates to about 35-percent of the weekly gross wage. Most all POCs are hired an "on-call" weekly status and are basically paid a flat rate per week, no matter how many or few hours they work. Working conditions can vary on the medium (half-hour, hour-long television, reality, live, soap and feature) and daily hours can range from 8 to 16 hour days. The POC is often the first person in the office and the last to leave since they hold the responsibility of tending to the needs of the crew.
More recent attempts have been made by Local 871 to establish a scale rate for the POCs, but to date all have been unsuccessful.
The union has a relaxed jurisdiction over the position since it does not have an official job description for a POC. It also governs another junior position in the category called Assistant Production Coordinator or APOC, but again since it does not have an official job description in its bylaws, many studios are able to avoid hiring the APOC.
== References == {{reflist}}
{{film crew}}

{{coord|29|36|28.24|N|52|33|9.25|E|region:IR|display=title}} [[File:Qavam House (11993601613).jpg|Front facade of building with painting of "Lion and Sun" (the Qajar royal emblem) on the [[pediment]].|thumb|250px]] '''Qavam House''' (also widely called "'''Narenjestan e Ghavam'''") is a traditional and historical house in [[Shiraz, Iran]]. It is at walking distance from the Khan Madrassa.
It was built between 1879 and 1886<ref>[http://www.caroun.com/Museums/IranMuseum/IranMRegion1/Narenjestan.htm Iran Museums: Fars Province (Shiraz), "Narenjestan Garden and Museum"]</ref> by Mirza Ibrahim Khan. The [[Qavam family]] were merchants originally from [[Qazvin]]. But they soon became active in the government during the [[Zand dynasty]], followed by the [[Qajar dynasty|Qajar]], and [[Pahlavi dynasty]] as well.
The Qavam "Naranjestan" preserves the elegance and refinement enjoyed by the upper-class families during the 19th century. The paintings on the low ceilings of the house are inspired by [[Victorian era|Victorian]] era Europe.
The mirrored porch was a focal point of the house, overlooking a small garden that was designed with fountains, [[date palm]]s, and flowering plants.
During the second Pahlavi era, the House became the headquarters of [[Pahlavi University]]'s [[Asia Institute]], directed by [[Arthur Upham Pope]] and [[Richard Nelson Frye]]. Frye and his family also lived in the house for a while.
The house today is a [[museum]] and is open to the public.
==Gallery==
<gallery mode="packed"> File:Naranjestan e Qavam - panoramio - Alireza Shakernia (1).jpg|View of the yard and the building in Spring. File:Qavam House, Shiraz 06.jpg|Interior of the house File:Qavam House, Shiraz 07.jpg|Interior of the house File:Qavam Garden, Shiraz 01.jpg|View of the garden from the house. File:Deevar qavam.jpg|Wall painting in the front side of the garden depicting 3 Qajari figures. File:Nāranjestān-e Ghavām.jpg|It is taken in 2018 from Nāranjestān-e Ghavām's pool and stone façade. </gallery>
==See also== *[[Architecture of Iran]] *[[Eram garden]] *[[Traditional Persian residential architecture]]

revision.comment: picture of a scroll showing the direction of writing perpendicular to how used in a Rotulus

revision.text:
{{about|the term|the album by John Zorn|Simulacrum (album)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}}
A '''simulacrum''' ([[plural]]: '''simulacra''' from {{lang-la|simulacrum}}, which means "likeness, similarity") is a representation or imitation of a person or thing.<ref>{{cite web |title=Word of the Day |date=1 May 2003 |publisher=dictionary.com |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/wordoftheday/archive/2003/05/01.html |accessdate=2 May 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070217130815/http://dictionary.reference.com/wordoftheday/archive/2003/05/01.html |archivedate=17 February 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The word was first recorded in the English language in the late 16th century, used to describe a representation, such as a statue or a painting, especially of a god. By the late 19th century, it had gathered a secondary association of inferiority: an image without the substance or qualities of the original.<ref>"simulacrum" ''The New Shorter Oxford English Dictionary'' 1993</ref> Philosopher [[Fredric Jameson]] offers [[photorealism]] as an example of artistic simulacrum, where a painting is sometimes created by copying a photograph that is itself a copy of the real.<ref name="anu.edu.au">Massumi, Brian. [http://www.anu.edu.au/hrc/first_and_last/works/realer.htm "Realer than Real: The Simulacrum According to Deleuze and Guattari."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100523090754/http://www.anu.edu.au/hrc/first_and_last/works/realer.htm |date=23 May 2010 }} retrieved 2 May 2007</ref> Other art forms that play with simulacra include [[trompe-l'œil]],<ref>Baudrillard, Jean. ''Simulacra and Simulations.'' transl. Sheila Faria Glaser. [http://www.egs.edu/faculty/jean-baudrillard/articles/simulacra-and-simulations-xi-holograms/ "XI. Holograms."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527153531/http://www.egs.edu/faculty/jean-baudrillard/articles/simulacra-and-simulations-xi-holograms/ |date=27 May 2010 }} retrieved 5 May 2010</ref> [[Pop Art|pop art]], [[Italian neorealism]], and [[French New Wave]].<ref name="anu.edu.au" />
==Philosophy== Simulacra have long been of interest to philosophers. In his ''[[Sophist (dialogue)|Sophist]]'', [[Plato]] speaks of two kinds of image making. The first is a faithful reproduction, attempted to copy precisely the original. The second is intentionally distorted in order to make the copy appear correct to viewers. He gives the example of [[Art in ancient Greece|Greek statuary]], which was crafted larger on the top than on the bottom so that viewers on the ground would see it correctly. If they could view it in scale, they would realize it was malformed. This example from the visual arts serves as a [[metaphor]] for the philosophical arts and the tendency of some philosophers to distort truth so that it appears accurate unless viewed from the proper angle.<ref>{{cite book |author=Plato |title=The Sophist |others=Translated by Benjamin Jowett |url=http://philosophy.eserver.org/plato/sophist.txt |accessdate=2 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051230161511/http://philosophy.eserver.org/plato/sophist.txt |archivedate=30 December 2005 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Friedrich Nietzsche|Nietzsche]] addresses the concept of simulacrum (but does not use the term) in the ''[[Twilight of the Idols]]'', suggesting that most philosophers, by ignoring the reliable input of their senses and resorting to the constructs of language and reason, arrive at a distorted copy of reality.<ref>{{cite book |last=Nietzsche |first=Friedrich |chapter=Reason in Philosophy |title=Twilight of the Idols |others=Translated by Walter Kaufmann and R. J. Hollingdale |year=1888 |url=http://www.handprint.com/SC/NIE/GotDamer.html#sect3 |accessdate=2 May 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070426104633/http://www.handprint.com/SC/NIE/GotDamer.html#sect3 |archivedate=26 April 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Postmodernism/Philosophy|Postmodernist]] French [[social theorist]] [[Jean Baudrillard]] argues that a simulacrum is not a copy of the real, but becomes truth in its own right: the [[Hyperreality|hyperreal]]. Where Plato saw two types of representation—faithful and intentionally distorted (simulacrum)—Baudrillard sees four: (1) basic reflection of reality; (2) perversion of reality; (3) pretence of reality (where there is no model); and (4) simulacrum, which "bears no relation to any reality whatsoever".<ref name="Simulacra and Simulations">[http://www.stanford.edu/dept/HPS/Baudrillard/Baudrillard_Simulacra.html Baudrillard Simulacra] retrieved 2 May 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040209024621/http://www.stanford.edu/dept/HPS/Baudrillard/Baudrillard_Simulacra.html |date=9 February 2004 }}</ref> In Baudrillard's concept, like Nietzsche's, simulacra are perceived as negative, but another modern philosopher who addressed the topic, [[Gilles Deleuze]], takes a different view, seeing simulacra as the avenue by which an accepted [[Ideal (ethics)|ideal]] or "privileged position" could be "challenged and overturned".<ref>{{cite book |last=Deleuze |first=Gilles |title=Difference and Repetition |others=Translated by Paul Patton |publisher=Columbia University Press |location=Columbia |year=1968 |pages=69}}</ref> Deleuze defines simulacra as "those systems in which different relates to different ''by means of'' difference itself. What is essential is that we find in these systems no ''prior [[Identity (philosophy)|identity]]'', no ''internal resemblance''".<ref>p. 299.</ref>
[[Alain Badiou]], in speaking with reference to Nazism about Evil, writes,<ref>{{cite book |last=Badiou |first=Alain |title=Ethics - An Essay on the Understanding of Evil|others=Translated by Peter Hallward |publisher=Verso |location=London |year=2001 |pages=74}}</ref> "fidelity to a simulacrum, unlike fidelity to an event, regulates its break with the situation not by the universality of the void, but by the closed particularity of an abstract set ... (the 'Germans' or the 'Aryans')".
==Recreation== Recreational simulacra include [[historical reenactment|reenactments of historical events]] or replicas of landmarks, such as [[Colonial Williamsburg]] and the [[Eiffel Tower]], and constructions of fictional or cultural ideas, such as [[Fantasyland]] at [[The Walt Disney Company]]'s [[Magic Kingdom]]. The various Disney parks have by some philosophers been regarded as the ultimate recreational simulacra, with Baudrillard noting that [[Walt Disney World Resort]] is a copy of a copy, "a simulacrum to the second power".<ref>Baudrillard, Jean. transl. Francois Debrix. Liberation. 4 March 1996. [http://www.egs.edu/faculty/jean-baudrillard/articles/disneyworld-company/ "Disneyworld Company."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527152759/http://www.egs.edu/faculty/jean-baudrillard/articles/disneyworld-company/ |date=27 May 2010 }} retrieved 5 May 2010.</ref> In 1975, Italian author [[Umberto Eco]] argued that at Disney's parks, "we not only enjoy a perfect imitation, we also enjoy the conviction that imitation has reached its apex and afterwards reality will always be inferior to it".<ref>Eco, Umberto. ''Travels in Hyperreality.'' Reproduced in relevant portion at [http://www.acsu.buffalo.edu/~breslin/eco_robots.html "The City of Robots"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060912200642/http://www.acsu.buffalo.edu/~breslin/eco_robots.html |date=12 September 2006 }} retrieved 2 May 2007</ref> This is for some an ongoing concern. Examining the impact of Disney's simulacrum of [[national park]]s, [[Disney's Wilderness Lodge]], environmentalist Jennifer Cypher and [[anthropologist]] Eric Higgs expressed worry that "the boundary between artificiality and reality will become so thin that the artificial will become the centre of moral value".<ref>Cypher, Jennifer and Eric Higgs. [http://www.ethics.ubc.ca/papers/invited/cypher-higgs.html "Colonizing the Imagination: Disney's Wilderness Lodge".] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070704185846/http://www.ethics.ubc.ca/papers/invited/cypher-higgs.html |date=4 July 2007 }} retrieved 2 May 2007</ref> Eco also refers to commentary on watching sports as sports to the power of three, or sports cubed. First, there are the players who participate in the sport (the real), then the onlookers merely witnessing it, and finally the commentary on the act of witnessing the sport. Visual artist [[Paul McCarthy]] has created entire installations based on ''Pirates of the Caribbean'' and theme park simulacra, with videos playing inside the installation.
==Caricature== An interesting example of simulacrum is [[caricature]]. When an artist produces a line drawing that closely approximates the facial features of a real person, the subject of the sketch cannot be easily identified by a random observer; it can be taken for a likeness of any individual. However, a caricaturist exaggerates prominent facial features, and a viewer will pick up on these features and be able to identify the subject, even though the caricature bears far less actual resemblance to the subject.
==Iconography== Beer (1999: p. 11) employs the term "simulacrum" to denote the formation of a sign or iconographic image, whether [[iconic]] or [[aniconic]], in the landscape or greater field of [[Thangka]] art and Tantric Buddhist [[iconography]]. For example, an iconographic [[Representation (arts)|representation]] of a cloud formation sheltering a deity in a thanka or covering the auspice of a [[sacred mountain]] in the natural environment may be discerned as a simulacrum of an "auspicious canopy" (Sanskrit: [[Chhatra]]) of the [[Ashtamangala]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Beer |first=Robert |year=1999 |title=The Encyclopedia of Tibetan Symbols and Motifs |publisher=Shambhala Publications |isbn=978-1-57062-416-2 |page=11}}</ref> [[Perceptions of religious imagery in natural phenomena]] approach a [[cultural universal]] and may be proffered as evidence of the natural creative spiritual engagement of the experienced environment endemic to the [[human psychology]].
==Word usage== The Latinised plural ''simulacra'' is interchangeable with the anglicised version ''simulacrums''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/simulacrum |title=simulacrum |publisher=Merriam-Webster |accessdate=12 April 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150712155454/http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/simulacrum |archivedate=12 July 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Memetics]] * ''[[Simulacra and Simulation]]'' * [[Simulated reality]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{wiktionary}} * [http://www.depauw.edu/sfs/backissues/55/baudrillard55art.htm "Two Essays: Simulacra and Science Fiction; Ballard’s ''Crash''"] Baudrillard, Jean * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070401234222/http://www.cinestatic.com/trans-mat/Fisher/FC3s2.htm "The Simulacrum's Revenge," sec 3.2 of ''Flatline Constructs: Gothic and Cybernetic-Theory Fiction''] Fisher, Mark
{{Appropriation in the Arts}}

revision.text:
{{Italic title}} [[File:Georgia O'Keeffe, The Flag, watercolor, 1918, MAM.tif|thumb|''The Flag'', watercolor and graphite on paper, {{cvt|12|×|8+3/4|in|cm}}, 1918, [[Milwaukee Art Museum]]]] '''''The Flag''''' is a painting by [[Georgia O'Keeffe]] (1918), that represents her anxiety about her brother being sent to fight in Europe during [[World War I]], a war that was particularly dangerous due to the uses of new and especially dangerous weapons and tactics, like [[mustard gas]], [[naval mine]]s, high-powered guns, and [[Aviation in World War I|aerial combat]]. It was not displayed until 1968, in part because anti-war sentiment was criminalized with the [[Espionage Act of 1917]].<ref name="MAM" /><ref name="Robinson p. 192" /><ref name="NYT" /> It is in the collection of the [[Milwaukee Art Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!387953~!0#focus|title=The Flag|website=Smithsonian Institution Research Information System|accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref><ref name="MAM">{{cite web|url=http://collection.mam.org/details.php?id=9929|title=The Flag|website=Milwaukee Art Museum|accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
==Background== {{quote box|align=right|width=33%|text=Everything seems to be whirling or unbalanced—I'm suspended in the air—can't get my feet on the ground... I should think going to war would be a great relief from this everlasting reading about it—thinking about it—hearing talk about it—whether one believed in it or not—it is a state that exists and experiencing it in reality seems preferable to the way we are all being soaked with it second hand—it is everywhere… it's all like a bad dream.|author=—Georgia O'Keeffe in a letter to [[Paul Strand]].<ref name="Robinson p. 192">{{cite book|author1=Roxana Robinson|author2=Georgia O'Keeffe|title=Georgia O'Keeffe: A Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_dRU2c1LPcYC&pg=PA192|year=1989|publisher=UPNE|isbn=978-0-87451-906-8|pages=192–193}}</ref>}} In 1918, O'Keeffe was in a state of depression and anxiety about the war and did not paint for three months. While she understood why it was important militarily, she found it at odds with [[humanism]] and basic [[Christianity|Christian]] beliefs.<ref name="Robinson p. 191">{{cite book|author1=Roxana Robinson|author2=Georgia O'Keeffe|title=Georgia O'Keeffe: A Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_dRU2c1LPcYC&pg=PA191|year=1989|publisher=UPNE|isbn=978-0-87451-906-8|pages=191–192}}</ref> O'Keeffe's brother, Alexius<ref name="ABJ" /> or Alexis, was stationed in a military camp in Texas before he shipped out for Europe during [[World War I]]. She visited him in the fall of 1917 before he was shipped overseas, and was anxious about his fate.<ref name="NYT" /> He was one of the first soldiers sent to France and did not believe that he would return to the United States alive.<ref name="Robinson p. 191" /> In France war had become very dangerous due to chemical and technologically advanced weapons. Poisonous gases were used against troops, which could kill, blind, or severely injure them. High-powered and long-range guns could cause significant destruction. Submarines planted mines in the seas and airplanes dropped weapons from the sky.<ref name="NYT">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/05/arts/design/review-world-war-i-the-quick-the-dead-the-artists.html|title=World War I — The Quick. The Dead. The Artists|website=New York Times|author=Holland Cotter|date=January 5, 2017|accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
O’Keeffe found herself at odds with people in [[Canyon, Texas|Canyon]] about the war and was discouraged by attempts to glorify it.<ref name="ABJ" /> She tried to persuade her male students to continue their education, rather than fight in the war<ref name="Robinson p. 191" /> and she also wanted authorities to create a course for young men about the reasons and causes of war before they engaged in battle.<ref name="ABJ" /> She created a stir when she asked a shop owner to remove Christmas cards from his shop that expressed anti-German sentiment.<ref name="Robinson p. 192" /> O'Keeffe became quite ill from [[influenza]] during the [[1918 flu pandemic]], which had killed an estimated 20 million people worldwide, and took a leave of absence from her teaching position at the [[West Texas State Normal College]] in early 1918 to recuperate at a friend's ranch in San Antonio,<ref name="ABJ">{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/156926133/|title=Watercolors Expand View of O'Keeffe|newspaper=Albuquerque Journal|author=Malin Wilson|via=newspapers.com|date=April 16, 1998|accessdate=January 15, 2017}}</ref> where she painted ''The Flag''.<ref>{{cite book|author=Nancy Hopkin Reily|title=Georgia O’Keeffe, A Private Friendship, Part I: Walking the Sun Prairie Land|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T2gHBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA270|date=December 1, 2014|publisher=Sunstone Press|isbn=978-1-63293-042-2|pages=270–271}}</ref>
==Overview== ''The Flag'', both a political statement and a reflection of her fears, is a red streak "bleeding into bruise-colored clouds".<ref name="NYT" /> In December 1917, she wrote that she felt compelled for the first time to paint from a sense of necessity. Her image for the painting was of a flag floating in the wind, similar to a tremble.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Georgia O'Keeffe|author2=Alfred Stieglitz|title=My Faraway One: Selected Letters of Georgia O'Keeffe and Alfred Stieglitz: Volume One, 1915–1933|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uNkuyi_Fg3YC&pg=PA446|date=June 21, 2011|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-16630-9|page=446}}</ref> Author [[Roxana Barry Robinson]] states, "O'Keeffe sets a drooping flag against a starless, darkening sky. The flag flutters limply, stripped of its stars and stripes; its only color, and that of the pole, is blood red."<ref name="Robinson p. 192" /> Alexis died in France due to the effects of mustard gas.<ref name="NYT" />
Anti-war sentiment was criminalized with the [[Espionage Act of 1917]],<ref name="NYT" /> and people living in Canyon were uneasy due to her anti-war position.<ref name="Robinson p. 192" /> ''The Flag'' was in the private collection of Mrs. Harry Lynde Bradley in October 25, 1968, when it was part of a [[Milwaukee Art Museum]] exhibition, and was acquired by the museum in 1977.<ref name="MAM" /> The painting is included in the "World War I and American Art" exhibition opened by the [[Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts]] in January 2017. After about a four-month run it will travel to the [[New-York Historical Society]], where it will be shown until September 3, 2017.<ref name="MAM" /><ref name="NYT" />
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{Georgia O'Keeffe}}
